transcript.title: Indonesiaâs Decision on East Timor
transcript.content:
I welcome the historic decision of Indonesiaâs Peopleâs Consultative Assembly (MPR) to approve the separation of East Timor from Indonesia.

The decision faithfully implements the freely expressed will of the majority of the East Timorese people.

It marks a new start for East Timor.

The decision is also a milestone in Indonesiaâs progress towards democracy, beginning with the general elections last June. It will be welcomed by the international community.

The decision will be welcomed by all Australians.

Once the consequential steps are finalised in Indonesia, a United Nations Transitional Authority, UNTAET, will take responsibility for the administration of East Timor and prepare it for independence.

The multinational force, INTERFET, to which sixteen countries are now contributing, is making good progress in restoring peace and security. It will continue until a UN peacekeeping force is ready to take over.

Australia is committed to continuing to work closely with both East Timor and Indonesia to ensure that the transition to independence for East Timor proceeds as smoothly as possible.

The Australian Government has undertaken to play a significant role in helping East Timor establish itself. The Government also looks forward to rebuilding Australiaâs relationship with Indonesia on the basis of the many important interests that our countries share.

20 October 1999
